event: Here is the table of events and timestamps:
29 years old
male
hospitalized for cardiogenic shock
diagnosed with biventricular failure
imaging concerning for myopericarditis and constrictive physiology
peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line placed
discharged on milrinone
presented to Emergency Department with septic shock
PICC line removed
started on IV vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam
transferred to intensive care unit for vasopressor support
Chryseobacterium indologenes grew from his admission PICC line and peripheral blood cultures
PICC line dressing became contaminated with tap water
antibiotics were changed to ciprofloxacin and piperacillin/tazobactam
he was weaned off vasopressor support
underwent pericardiectomy
completed 14 days of antibiotics
discharged from the hospital off inotropes with stable vital signs and labs
seen in outpatient cardiology clinic, remains in good health with no evidence of recurrent infection
progressive fatigue and dyspnoea on exertion for 2–3 months
hospitalized for non-ischaemic cardiomyopathy
diagnosed with non-ischaemic cardiomyopathy
computed tomography angiography of the coronary arteries revealed cardiomegaly
echocardiogram showed biventricular failure
cardiac magnetic resonance imaging showed a left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) of 23%
diastolic septal bounce and a concentrically thickened pericardium
atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response requiring radiofrequency ablation
cardiogenic shock
stabilized on inotrope therapy
discharged on home milrinone infusion via a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC line)
fever of 38.7°C (101.8°F) and chills for 1 day at home
tachycardia with a heart rate in the 110s
blood pressure of 96/57 mmHg
heart that was tachycardic, but normal rhythm without any murmurs, rubs, or gallops
no signs of elevated jugular venous pressure and he did not have lower extremity oedema
bilateral radial and dorsalis pedis pulses were equal and 2+ bilaterally
lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally in the anterior and posterior lung fields with a normal work of breathing
no redness or drainage around the PICC line
Chest X-ray showed no abnormalities
electrocardiogram was significant for sinus tachycardia
sinus tachycardia, normal axis, RSR′ pattern in V1, QRS duration of 90 ms, and non-specific T wave flattening in the inferolateral leads
removed his PICC line
became febrile to 39.5°C (103.1°F) and developed severe rigours as well as hypotension with blood pressure in 70s/40s mmHg
elevated lactate level of 5.5 mmol/L
blood cultures were drawn both peripherally and from the PICC line
started on empiric vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam
transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit for vasopressor support
Gram-negative rods which later speciated as Chryseobacterium indologenes
PICC line as the most likely source of infection
antibiotics were changed to ciprofloxacin and piperacillin/tazobactam
he was weaned off vasopressor support
underwent pericardiectomy
completed 14 days of antibiotics
discharged from the hospital off inotropes with stable vital signs and labs
seen in outpatient cardiology clinic, remains in good health with no evidence of recurrent infection
